Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 7c1dc7ea0b3eec79518b6dcb9552256bfc1cec15
This will fail to build until https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/62456 is merged into libpldm.
Probably worth a comment that this is to enable the poll APIs in libpldm?
Ack
Would it not be more maintainable to make these `TEST_F()` instead of just `TEST()`? Leaving them as `TEST()` forces the manual setup and cleanup as you have below. `TEST_F()` would automate it.
I've cleaned this up a bit so we at least take advantage of RAII for cleanup
I think we just inline this in the header now? Not sure why we should keep the `.cpp` lying around.
Done

Is there any benefit to passing a `InstanceIdDb` instance instead? That way you could have a single constructor for `Requester` and the caller makes the decision about how the `InstanceIdDb` is configured.
Done
This feels like there are too many layers of indirection...
Ignore this, InstanceIdDb is useful as it wraps the libpldm APIs without the user requiring knowledge of DBus embedded in `pldm::dbus_api::Requester`.
We need to do something more informative than just kill pldmd with no explanation.
Done
Same here.
Done
This is better, though it would be a further improvement to log a message before throwing the exception.
Done
Unnecessary change?
Done
Unnescessary changing.
Done

next function throws two different types of exceptions
std::runtime_error (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/62580/12/pldmd/instance_id.hpp#54)
std::system_category().default_error_condition (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/62580/12/pldmd/instance_id.hpp#59)

Need to catch those exceptions use catch{} and handle properly.

Or do you expect the caller of getInstanceIs to catch the exceptions?

I've changed it so we throw TooManyResources if there are no instance ids available (like before this change). I think throwing std::system_category().default_error_condition if there is something wrong with the instance ID database is reasonable. If there is something wrong with that, there is nothing we can do here to fix it. 

Do you agree?

> next function throws two different types of exceptions
> std::runtime_error (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/62580/12/pldmd/instance_id.hpp#54)

Yep, the `std::runtime_error` should be handled as outlined in the comment below.

> std::system_category().default_error_condition (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/62580/12/pldmd/instance_id.hpp#59)
> 
> Need to catch those exceptions use catch{} and handle properly.
> 
> Or do you expect the caller of getInstanceIs to catch the exceptions?

There's nothing sensible we can do for exceptions other than the `std::runtime_error` when the instance IDs are exhausted. We can't reliably send PLDM messages if we can't reliably allocate instance IDs. Thus not attempting to handle the exception is the right course of action.
Ack
We will never enter this path where rc is set to -EAGAIN. This condition should be covered under catch.
Good spot. Fixed.

Right, but you haven't answered the question of what to put in the body of that catch statement. There's almost nothing sensible you can do, the database is in an inoperable state and you can't exchange PLDM messages. There's no point trying to salvage the situation. We might as well let pldmd abort out as this at least gives us accurate information about what the problem was and where it occurred.

Specifically, see this anti-pattern:

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/anti-patterns.md#handling-unexpected-error-codes-and-exceptions
The only thing we can do is exit with error code than crashing/aborting PLDM. But really not sure if that is preferred.

As no specific action to be taken after instance id failure and PLDM abort will give us accurate information about what the problem was and where it occurred. I accept to not handle the exception std::system_category().default_error_condition.
Why the libpldm dependency be a dependency for pldmd?

Some APIs in `libpldm` depend on `poll.h` which is specified by POSIX and not the the C standard. When `libpldm` is used in freestanding environments (hostboot, skiboot, host firmware in general) POSIX is irrelevant. We guard the declaration of functions requiring `struct poll` with `#if HAVE_POLL` in the libpldm headers to make life easy for those integrating libpldm into freestanding environments.

As C and C++ just copy/paste libpldm headers into the the pldmd translation units via the preprocessor, pldmd also needs to define `HAVE_POLL` in order to gain access to the `struct poll`-based APIs in libpldm.
We don't actually need this just yet (plus I got it wrong, it's `PLDM_HAS_POLL`). So deleting for now and will add it when it's actually needed.
please add doxygen for params

Handle return code?
Done
Why is instance ID type changed from `uint8_t` to `int`?
Done
`pldm_instance_db* pldmInstanceIdDb = nullptr`
Ack

lower_camel_case for filenames is the pattern in pldm repo.
test-instance-id.hpp -> test_instance_id.hpp
Ack
`static_cast<uintmax_t>(PLDM_MAX_TIDS * pldmMaxInstanceIds)`

`static_cast<uintmax_t>(PLDM_MAX_TIDS) * pldmMaxInstanceIds` is I think what was intended, but maybe not what was written. We should probably fix the declaration of `pldmMaxInstanceIds` also. Rather than use `auto` use `uintmax_t`.
Done
We can drop this too? See the diff between PS15 and PS16.
If you compare between base and PS16, this line is in it's OG place (it's used below). I have however added an extra blank line which I'll remove.
Ah, fair enough. I'll stop stepping on rakes at some point.
LGTM, minor comment.

nit: struct is not needed

`pldm_instance_db* pldmInstanceIdDb = nullptr;` should suffice
